has-[span.katex]:overflow-x-auto has-[span.katex]:overflow-y-hidden"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["Linear mappings from vectors to vectors can be represented by matrices in a familiar way, where the action of the linear mapping is described by matrix-vector multiplication.\nBut channels are linear mappings from matrices to matrices, not vectors to vectors.\nSo, ",["$","em",null,{"children":"in general"}],", how can we express channels in mathematical terms?"],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0 has-[span.katex]:overflow-x-auto has-[span.katex]:overflow-y-hidden"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"For some channels, we may have a simple formula that describes them, like for the three examples of non-unitary qubit channels described previously.\nBut an arbitrary channel may not have such a nice formula, so it isn't practical in general to express a channel in this way.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0 has-[span.katex]:overflow-x-auto has-[span.katex]:overflow-y-hidden"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["As a point of comparison, in the simplified formulation of quantum information we use ",["$","em",null,{"children":"unitary matrices"}]," to represent operations on quantum state vectors: every unitary matrix represents a valid operation and every valid operation can be expressed as a unitary matrix.\nIn essence, the question being asked is: How can we do something analogous for channels?"],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0 has-[span.katex]:overflow-x-auto has-[span.katex]:overflow-y-hidden"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["To answer this question, we'll require some additional mathematical machinery.\nWe'll see that channels can, in fact, be described mathematically in a few different ways, including representations named in honor of three individuals who played key roles in their development:\n",["$","$L13",null,{"definition":"William Forrest Stinespring (1929 – 2012) was a mathematician who specialized in operator theory, which is a topic in functional analysis having many interesting implications for quantum same if and only if they have the same Choi matrix.\nOne reason why this is important is that it provides us with a way of determining whether two different descriptions correspond to the same channel or to different channels: we simply compute the Choi matrices and compare them to see if they're equal.\nIn contrast, Stinespring and Kraus representations are not unique in this way, as we have seen."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0 has-[span.katex]:overflow-x-auto has-[span.katex]:overflow-y-hidden"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"Choi matrices are also useful in
